column1: The city of Edinburgh is renowned world-wide for its history
column3: scenery and cultural attractions. Built on a set of hills
column4: it is situated between the Firth of Forth to the north
column5: the Pentland Hills to the south
column6: and the council areas of East Lothian and West Lothian to the east and west. The population today is estimated at over 450
column7: 000 and is growing rapidly predominantly through migration. The economy is oriented to services
column8: particularly in the areas of finance
column9:
science and the professions.

There are signs of human activity in the area from at least c.5000 BC with fortifications evident from c.1000 BC. Celtic and Roman occupants were followed by Northumbrians and Scots. In the 15th Century it was made Scotland's capital
column10: but its importance as the political centre of Scotland was later diminished by the Union of 1707 with England. Later cultural and architectural achievements in the 18th and 19th centuries earned it the title 'Athens of the North'. Today
column11: Edinburgh is known world-wide as a tourist mecca
column13: and as the site of one of the world's largest international arts festivals
column15: the city's importance as a political centre was re-established with the opening of the Scottish Parliament in 1999.
